title: Harris v. State
text:
<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"
   "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">



<!-- meta anti cache-->
 



<!--
body{
font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}
-->



THIS
  OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
  PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      Ronnie Harris, Petitioner,
      v.
      State of South Carolina, Respondent.
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal from Greenville County
Â John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 2009-MO-006
  Submitted January 22, 2009 â€“ Filed
February 9, 2009Â Â  

DISMISSED AS IMPROVIDENTLY GRANTED


  
    
      
        Deputy
          Chief Appellate Defender WandaÂ  H. Carter, of South Carolina Commission on
          Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
        Attorney
          General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
          Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Karen
          Ratigan, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM: Â We
  granted a writ of certiorari to review the post-conviction relief courtâ€™s order
  denying relief to Petitioner. After
careful consideration of the record and briefs, the writ of certiorari is
DISMISSED AS IMPROVIDENTLY GRANTED.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE,
JJ., concur.

title: Hannah v. State
text:
<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"
   "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">



<!-- meta anti cache-->
 



<!--
body{
font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}
-->



THIS OPINION HAS
  NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Elijah Hannah, Petitioner,
        v.
        State of South Carolina, Respondent.
      
    
  


ORIGINAL JURISDICTION

Appeal From Florence County
James E. Brogdon, Jr., Trial Judge
B. Hicks Harwell, Jr., Post-Conviction
Relief Judge

Memorandum Opinion No.Â  2009-MO-007
  Submitted December 4, 2008 â€“ February 9,
2009Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Reynolds
          H. Blankenship, Jr., of Columbia, for Petitioner.
        Assistant
          Attorney General Molly R. Crum, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Because of the unusual procedural history
  of the underlying criminal matter and this post-conviction relief matter, we
  granted certiorari in our original jurisdiction.[1] Â We are presented with both direct appeal and post-conviction relief (PCR) issues.Â 
  We dismiss the direct appeal and affirm the PCR judgeâ€™s finding based on our
  standard of review.
As to the direct
  appeal issues, counsel for petitioner filed a brief pursuant to Anders v.
    California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967) and a petition to be relieved as counsel.Â 
  Petitioner has not filed a pro se response.Â  After a thorough review of
  the record pursuant to Anders, we dismiss the direct appeal and grant
  the petition to be relieved as counsel.
Regarding
  the sole PCR issue presented related to the service of notice of the Stateâ€™s
  intent to seek a sentence of life without parole, we hold there is evidence in
  the record to support the PCR courtâ€™s holding that Petitioner received proper
  notice.Â  We affirm pursuant to Rule 220, SCACR and the following authorities:Â  Pierce
    v. State, 338 S.C. 139, 144-45, 526 S.E.2d 222, 225 (2000) (â€œ[An appellate
  court] will uphold the findings of the PCR judge when there is any evidence of
  probative value to support them.â€); Cherry v. State, 300 S.C. 115, 119,
  386 S.E.2d 624, 626 (1989) (â€œThe appropriate scope of review of this Court is
  that â€˜any evidenceâ€™ of probative value is sufficient to uphold the PCR judgeâ€™s
  findings.â€).
Accordingly, in our
  original jurisdiction, counsel is relieved and the belated direct appeal is dismissed.Â 
  We further affirm the denial of post-conviction relief.
AFFIRMED.
TOAL,
  C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1] Petitioner was convicted and sentenced to life without parole for the
  offense of armed robbery, which was his second â€œmost serious offenseâ€ under section
  17-25-45 of the South Carolina Code (2003).Â  A direct appeal was not pursued.Â 
  Trial counselâ€™s failure to file a direct appeal led to Petitioner seeking a
  belated direct review pursuant to White v. State, 263 S.C. 110, 208
  S.E.2d 35 (1974) in this post-conviction relief action.Â  PCR counsel then
  failed to file a timely notice of appeal from the denial of post-conviction
  relief.Â  When the untimely appeal was presented to this Court, we accepted the
  matter in our original jurisdiction by granting a writ of certiorari rather
  than delaying the matter further by requiring Petitioner to file a second PCR
  action and seek belated review under Austin v. State, 305 S.C. 453, 409
  S.E.2d 395 (1991).

title: Jones v. State
text:
<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"
   "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">



<!-- meta anti cache-->
 



<!--
body{
font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}
-->



THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				David Jones, Respondent,
				v.
				State of South Carolina, Petitioner.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal from Pickens County
Â Larry R. Patterson, Post-Conviction Judge
Memorandum Opinion No.Â  2009-MO-008
Submitted January 22, 2009 â€“ Filed
  February 23, 2009Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
  Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General Karen
  Ratigan, all of Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Deputy
  Chief Appellate Defender Wanda H. Carter, of South Carolina Commission on
  Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â  We granted the Stateâ€™s petition to
  review an order granting respondent post-conviction relief (PCR) and now
  reverse, finding no evidence in the record to support the PCR judgeâ€™s findings
  that respondentâ€™s trial attorney was ineffective.Â  Miller v. State, 379
  S.C. 108, 665 S.E.2d 596 (2008) (standards for ineffective assistance of
  counsel and for appellate review).
REVERSED.
TOAL,
  C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

  granted certiorari to review the post-conviction relief courtâ€™s denial of

DISMISSED AS IMPROVIDENTLY GRANTED.
TOAL,
  C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur. BEATTY, J. not
  participating.

title: State v. McKenzie
text:
<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"
   "http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">



<!-- meta anti cache-->
 



<!--
body{
font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}
-->



THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				State of South Carolina, Petitioner,
				v.
				Frank McKenzie, Respondent.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Richland County
Â James R. Barber, Circuit Court Judge
Memorandum Opinion No.Â  2009-MO-012
Submitted February 19, 2009 â€“ Filed
  February 23, 2009Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
  Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Brian T.
  Petrano, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Deputy
  Chief Appellate Defender Wanda H. Carter, of South Carolina Commission on
  Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â  We granted the Stateâ€™s petition[1] to review an order granting
  respondent post-conviction relief (PCR) and now reverse, finding no evidence in
  the record to support the PCR courtâ€™s findings that respondentâ€™s plea counsel
  was ineffective.Â  Pierce v. State, 338 S.C. 139, 144-45, 526 S.E.2d 222,
  224-25 (2000) (setting forth the analytical framework for establishing ineffective
  assistance of counsel and noting that when â€œno probative evidenceâ€ supports the
  PCR courtâ€™s ruling it will not be upheld).Â  
REVERSED.
TOAL,
  C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1]  McKenzie pleaded guilty to charges from both Lexington and Richland County.Â  The PCR Court granted relief on all charges and the State petitioned this
  Court for a writ of certiorari.Â  We denied the petition as to the Lexington County charges.Â  This opinion concerns only the Richland County charge.Â
